etymology.description: Originally a pictogram of a mouth full of teeth; later phono-semantic: semantic ‘teeth’ + phonetic 止.
etymology.interpretation: First represented rows of teeth inside a mouth, making the meaning visually obvious. It was later analyzed as a phono-semantic compound, using 止 for sound while retaining the tooth meaning in the overall form.
etymology.simplification: Simplified from 齒 by compressing and streamlining the complex strokes of the tooth radical, reducing interior lines for stroke economy.

examples.chinese: 孩子换牙时(孩子換牙時)，乳齿会逐渐脱落(乳齒會逐漸脫落)。
examples.pinyin: Háizi huàn yá shí, rǔchǐ huì zhújiàn tuōluò.
examples.english: When children change their teeth, the milk teeth gradually fall out.

examples.chinese: 这把锯的齿很锋利(這把鋸的齒很鋒利)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè bǎ jù de chǐ hěn fēnglì.
examples.english: The teeth of this saw are very sharp.

examples.chinese: 他年纪大了(他年紀大了)，牙齿不太好了(牙齒不太好了)。
examples.pinyin: Tā niánjì dà le, yáchǐ bú tài hǎo le.
examples.english: He’s getting older, and his teeth aren’t in great condition.
